data.title: The Earl of Home obituary
data.meta_description: When Sir Alec Douglas-Home disclaimed his peerage in 1963 to become prime minister, his son David also dropped his courtesy title, Lord Dunglass. David was a st
data.text:
When Sir Alec Douglas-Home disclaimed his peerage in 1963 to become prime minister, his son David also dropped his courtesy title, Lord Dunglass. David was a student at Oxford at the time and DR Thorpe, his father’s biographer, noted: “When the instruments of renunciation had taken effect, the porters of Christ Church punctiliously set forth to the various staircases, painting out the words ‘Lord Dunglass’ and substituting ‘The Hon David Douglas-Home’, a correct adjustment.”

Yet the prospects of taking his place on the red benches were not lost. His father, who on leaving 10 Downing Street was re-ennobled with a life peerage as Baron Home of the Hirsel, had merely put the earldom into what his son called “cold storage”. After the former prime minister’s
